title: EA's day of reckoning is here after 'Star Wars' game uproar, $3 billion ...

embed.description: Electronic Arts' shareholders are running for the hills this month and for good reason. The company's profitable business model is now at risk after angry gamers revolted over its aggressive in-game moneymaking strategy in "Star Wars Battlefront II."

body:
Please pay attention riot


  


EA's day of reckoning is here after 'Star Wars' game uproar, $3 billion in stock value wiped out
Leading gaming YouTube personalities believe EA will be forced to change its practices after the "Star Wars Battlefront II" micro-transaction controversy.
"After the communal and political backlash EA received over Battlefront II, the industry at large is going to have to walk back its loot box plans a little," Jim Sterling writes in an email.

https://www.cnbc.com/2017/11/28/eas-day-of-reckoning-is-here-after-star-wars-game-uproar.html

If value is being wiped off a game with an up front price because of loot boxes, what will happen to a game which relies on loot boxes for revenue in the absence of an up front price?

replies.body:
Hopefully this means that developers will be re-evaluating how they look at the video game industry. Ideally, this will make lootboxes (at least, those purchasable with real money, or an in-game currency bought with real money) a thing of the past, and that developers will change the monetisation of their games to be "pay-for-aesthetic-options", rather than the typical "pay-to-win/progress" that has become the norm these days. Hopefully, games with an upfront cost that rely on in-game purchases for profit will go for a different type of optional in-game purchase system rather than simply increasing the upfront price of the game. I'd hate to see games like Overwatch skyrocket in price because they simply gave up on their "player optional" monetisation options, and even more-so for "free-to-play" games introducing upfront costs in the wake of this.

When all is said and done, we can only hope this is a wake-up call for everyone, developers and gamers alike, which will result in a "balanced" experience between enjoy-ability, accessibility and monetisation (and I feel like there's something else I'm missing here?).

I really hope so. Lootboxes need to be consigned to the bin of history.

I mean, I don't have nearly as big of a problem with loot boxes as a lot of people *personally* as long as they are only for cosmetics. As far as I'm concerned if it's cosmetic only then there's no coercion there because it's basically the same principle as buying a mystery gift. 

That said, I'm not a x age kid with little to no real life experience or concept of monetary value and for that demographic I agree that it can be very harmful. Which is precisely why gambling has an 18+ age gate (and frankly I think it should be more or a 18+ and have had to manage paying rent or some other consistent bill for at least 6 months gate). Kids, especially those paying for this stuff with their parents money and not their own have no concept of worth and shouldn't have access to this sorta chance stuff until they do.

I have no problem with a free to play game making money off cosmetics, but holy shit EA have been shooting at the ground long enough I'm glad they finally shot themselves in the foot because really, they've been taking the piss for far too long.

> I mean, I don't have nearly as big of a problem with loot boxes as a lot of people personally as long as they are only for cosmetics. As far as I'm concerned if it's cosmetic only then there's no coercion there because it's basically the same principle as buying a mystery gift.

See the issue with this is the Champion aspect of loot boxes, If you want a champion you need to open a box an  hope for the best, if you get a champion you want, congrats! You need more Blue Essence to unlock it and that's done by even more RNG. Oh, You didn't get a champion you needed to get enough Blue Essence? Just play another 7 games and have another shot.
I mean we're more talking about the paid aspect of loot boxes more than the champion capsules. That's a whole 'nother can of worms. Like I said, I have no real problem *if* they're only cosmetic.
Lets hope they take a bite of humble pie
